articles.headline: A Rebounding Economy Remains Fragile for Many
articles.snippet: Gains that have been strong for people who live in large metropolitan centers have not reached people who live in rural areas, industrial centers and Appalachia.
articles.abstract: Gains that have been strong for people who live in large metropolitan centers have not reached people who live in rural areas, industrial centers and Appalachia.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The eye-popping improvement in economic fortunes last year raises the question: If incomes are up and poverty is down, why is Donald J. Trump’s message of economic decay resonating so broadly?
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum, Patricia Cohen and Jack Healy

articles.headline: New Records Shed Light on Donald Trump’s $25,000 Gift to Florida Official
articles.snippet: Documents obtained this week by The New York Times, including a copy of Mr. Trump’s check, at least partly undercut a timeline that looked like a quid pro quo.
articles.abstract: Documents obtained this week by The New York Times, including a copy of Mr. Trump’s check, at least partly undercut a timeline that looked like a quid pro quo.
articles.lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — It was Aug. 29, 2013, an unremarkable day inside Florida’s whitewashed Capitol, and a typically sweltering one outside among the moss-bearded oaks and sabal palms. Around 3:45 p.m., Jennifer Meale, the communications director for Attorney General Pam Bondi, fielded a seemingly routine call from a financial reporter for The Orlando Sentinel. The attorney general of New York had recently filed a lawsuit against Donald J. Trump alleging fraud in the marketing of Trump University’s real estate and wealth-building seminars. Had Florida ever conducted its own investigation, the reporter asked.
articles.byline: By Kevin Sack and Steve Eder

articles.headline: Sowing Doubt Is Seen as Prime Danger in Hacking Voting System
articles.snippet: Disrupting the presidential election would be far easier than changing the outcome by computer hacking, officials say. But disruption may have already begun.
articles.abstract: Disrupting the presidential election would be far easier than changing the outcome by computer hacking, officials say. But disruption may have already begun.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russian hackers would not be able to change the outcome of the United States presidential election, the nation’s most senior intelligence and law enforcement officials have assured Congress and the White House in recent weeks.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: As Britain Confronts ‘Brexit,’ a Canadian Takes Center Stage: Mark Carney
articles.snippet: Mr. Carney, the first foreigner to head Britain’s central bank, is a crucial figure in the effort to manage the fallout of the so-called Brexit vote.
articles.abstract: Mr. Carney, the first foreigner to head Britain’s central bank, is a crucial figure in the effort to manage the fallout of the so-called Brexit vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a soggy morning in late June, as Britain absorbed the staggering news that it had voted to abandon the European Union, a stone-faced Canadian took to national television to offer assurances that the world was not ending.

articles.headline: Voters’ View of a Donald Trump Presidency: Big Risks and Rewards
articles.snippet: Hillary Clinton and Mr. Trump are locked in a close race, with voters saying he lacks the right temperament but would bring real change to Washington, a New York Times/CBS News poll showed.
articles.abstract: Hillary Clinton and Mr. Trump are locked in a close race, with voters saying he lacks the right temperament but would bring real change to Washington, a New York Times/CBS News poll showed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most voters consider Donald J. Trump a risky choice for president, saying he lacks the right temperament and values, but he is seen as more transformative and better at handling the economy than Hillary Clinton, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Dalia Sussman

articles.headline: Rodrigo Duterte Ordered Philippine Killings, Professed Hit Man Testifies
articles.snippet: A spokesman denied the charges against President Duterte, who was accused in a Senate hearing of presiding over 1,000 killings as mayor of Davao City.
articles.abstract: A spokesman denied the charges against President Duterte, who was accused in a Senate hearing of presiding over 1,000 killings as mayor of Davao City.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANILA — He was a member of a hit squad that killed hundreds over the years, taking part in about 50 of the murders himself. One victim was fed to crocodiles, he recalled, and four others were hanged and thrown into the sea.
articles.byline: By Felipe Villamor and Mike Ives

articles.headline: By One Measure, Health Care Law Is a Record Success
articles.snippet: While the number of people without health insurance is at its lowest, thanks largely to Obamacare, continued declines are far from certain.
articles.abstract: While the number of people without health insurance is at its lowest, thanks largely to Obamacare, continued declines are far from certain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Included among the many uplifting economic numbers released by the Census Bureau on Tuesday was a remarkable one about health insurance in the United States: Only 9.1 percent of Americans do not have coverage, the lowest level ever recorded by the agency.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Margot Sanger-Katz
